author: schravenralph
body:
The strategy was originally designed to augment the trading of ranging stocks that you wouldn't mind holding if the underlying ends up taking a big hit.

Now, with this concept, you are not protected against large downward swings. If you are particularly bullish on these stocks but want to sell volatility at the same time, by all means. But there's dollar-cost averaging to make your bet on the stocks, and there's more capital-efficient and direction-agnostic strategies such as iron condors and strangles to sell volatility and risk.

The Wheel does well on big names such as IBM and other stocks that aren't destined to shoot to the moon but are also incredibly stable. I wouldn't mind holding it at a discount and I wouldn't mind if by some miracle it breaks a 5-year record right.

This bias towards a stock can be asserted into a strategy by employing the Wheel, but to me the stocks listed don't qualify in remotely the same way.

author: Adventurous-Luck-103
body: Not all dividend stocks are created equal. Such as General Electric who dropped their dividend to I believe 1 cent. Look for companies with at least a 25 year history of paying and increasing dividends that’s why they are called the aristocrats. Coke, IBM , Proctor and Gamble come to mind. They are not exciting stocks their price doesn’t move to much historically. However when you buy the stock have the dividends reinvested than over time you see the magic  of compounding interest. There is an legend that Albert Einstein said compounding interest was the most powerful force in the universe. Not sure I believe it’s an actual quote , but it does get the message across. Not investment advice. Good luck.  Edit here is a list of aristocrats: https://news.yahoo.com/2021s-dividend-aristocrats-list-65-232153617.html

author: flyingmoose0913
body:
So my perspective is that those two are actually in very different places from a regulation perspective.  

Google is likely to get continually more regulated as time goes on and data privacy becomes a bigger issue.  I would say it doesn't actually fall under most current anti-trust legislation which is related to price competition and its revenue area is actually advertising where there is lots of competition BUT I agree that practically it is enough of a monopoly that it will likely get dragged into it.  I sold my Google and FB a few months ago, both just to take profits and because I think there's a solid chance they spend the next 2-4 years in continuous litigation and hearings over how to manage data more responsibly and how they should be regulated.  Doubt anyone can agree to anything, but it will put a damper on their acquisition and expansion sprees.

Amazon is a very different case as Amazon isn't really a monopoly in any way, they just compete in SO MANY categories that it feels that way.  But when you look at it...in e-commerce, its hard to call someone a monopoly when Walmart, Target, Costco Best Buy and every other big box compete with them; AWS is fighting tooth and nail with Microsoft Azure, Google could, IBM, Oracle etc.; 

We can keep going down the list - Prime video competes with Netflix and Hulu; Amazon logistics competes with UPS and Fedex and Uber Cargo...so while their everpresence in our lives makes it feel like it MUST be a monopoly, its actually hard to identify anywhere specifically that Amazon isn't subject to pretty intense competition by big players, thus hard to make a case for anti-competitive behavior or anti-trust violations.

author: turkeychicken
body:
Like others said, I think that's a good method to get started with investing in individual stocks.  I'm glad I did it that way when I started out.

For example, one of the first stocks I purchased was 2 shares of IBM when they were near their all time high in 2013.  I still own those two shares and I'm down 35% (-$186 total) on them.  I'm still holding them though, mostly as a reminder that things don't always work out the way you hope.

If I had saved up and dumped like 10k into IBM back then, I'd be really pissed haha.

Your gains might not seem like as much, but if you spent $1000 on 10 investments that all went up, it's not really much different than spending $1k on one investment that went up.

author: Viscoden
body:
Warren's philosophy revolves around value investing and buying what you know. Warren doesn't know tech, and he knows that he doesn't.

Investing is all about risk management; how much risk are you taking on for a realistic reward? What happens if you lose a large portion of your money? I personally don't want to spend an extra five to ten years not retired because of a stupid mistake trying to double my money.

It's not as simple as buying Apple or Microsoft and earning 30% average per year. There were many years where they traded sideways or downwards. Look at Microsoft from 2001 to 2014. Thirteen years of doodoo in terms of equity appreciation. It can happen again.

Many of the companies you see popularized today will not be around in 5 to 10 years. For some reason it is popular to lose money and then try to go public.

I wouldn't hesitate to call myself a value investor. One of my "top" holdings is eBay. I don't expect for eBay to 10x overnight, but I do believe that it is fundamentally undervalued, and that it is an e-commerce/tech company that pays a dividend. I'll probably still be holding this company in 10 years, and my dividend yield on cost should be pretty juicy at that point, so long as they continue to up the dividend. eBay is also relatively recession proof, as people will continue to buy and sell on their platform no matter what the economy looks like, which brings risk down.

I'm long MSFT, AAPL and EBAY.

The price of the larger companies you mentioned has a lot to do with how much money they are making. IBM is still a fantastic company, but they don't raise their earnings by much. They have quite a bit of debt based on a quick look at finviz, and their dividend payout ratio looks like it is 103%, which is a little "uh-oh", as it means they are paying out more than they can afford to, putting their dividend at risk.

There are lots of value plays out there. I think Utz is a good value. WMT or TGT are arguably value companies.


Sorry for the rambling; hope any of this helps!

author: Goddess_Peorth
body:
AMD is at a great price level right now, if your goal is long-term and you want something relatively safe.

IBM is a good long-term pick, too, though not everybody still agrees with that. But I do.

If you want something more speculative with a lot of potential, OPTT is great bet; a lot of people missed the mostly-local news about their latest R&D test installation that will soon be built in Oregon. But this one is speculative.

If you like EV, I think RIDE is a great buy right now, they're getting less retail interest because they're focused on fleet trucks, instead of consumer trucks.

I also like HYLN which is listed under industrials but designs and sells electric powertrains for EVs.

For med-tech I think THMO has huge potential, and is flying mostly under the radar right now.

GSK, however, is a safer long-term play.

(I own all these)

I know you are getting flack for this but I think you have a point - look at palisamo/ginetty at IBM buying back shares to hit their arbitrary EPS metric promise.

The company is the definition of stagnation so buy backs were a way to influence that metric.

I worked at IBM during that time and it was and still is a terrible place for 75% of the employees, that money did nothing to change IBMs ability to be competitive in the market.

I don't think buy backs are always negative but they are certainly a lever to pull and companies can pull that lever too much.

author: ilinula
body: IBM generates plenty of cash to cover its high dividend as well as share buy backs. What does that have to do with their ability to be competitive in the market? Free cash flow yield is a completely different metric, and it returns more value to shareholders for a company that is stagnating or declining. It's perfectly reasonable for them to buy back shares instead of sit on cash. I would prefer to hold a company like this than one that continually is able to be 'competitive in the market' but doesn't generate any cash so it has to issue shares year-over-year in order to supplement it's growth

* Allied Signal, Inc
* Aluminum Company of America
* American Can Company (lol)

* Chevron Corp

author: Artmasterx
body:
I am not sure what you mean by loss rate here.  The 2-qubit gate fidelity is the most relevant system parameter for systems today (it determines to a large degree the quantum circuit complexity that can be run), along with the number of qubits.  The Google Sycamore device has a 2-qubit gate fidelity of \~0.994, and that was a device developed in 2019.  It is not clear if they have anything better at this point, as most of their recent publications rely on Sycamore.

IonQ seems to claim to have a 32 qubit system that has a 2-qubit fidelity of 0.999, but they have not published data showing that.  I believe the 32 qubits.  My guess is that it is not quite that good yet on gate fidelity, otherwise they would have published.  Honeywell has shown data indicating their system is currently capable of 0.995-0.998.  I expect IonQ is similar at this point.

You can dismiss IBM, but they have a lot of excellent people working on hardware and algorithms.  I think they are probably behind Google at the moment on superconducting, but it would be wrong to dismiss them at this point.  

But honestly, what all these companies have right now is not really all that important in terms of what company may "win" the race.

author: Ytinerec
body:
Been doing this since I started investing in 2006. Last few years, the dividends collected has been 20K in 2018, 25k in 2019, 31K in 2020 (a couple cuts like DIS and SLB), expecting this year to be around 35K+. Regrets? I have none. I think I've done decently well and this approach has gotten me thru 2 recessions now so I feel somewhat comfortable with it.

I read some of the comments here and what I would caution people on is putting too much emphasis on classic high yield areas like utilities, REITs, or certain energy plays. These areas may look attractive from a current yield perspective but they typically come with drawbacks that are not immediately evident to newbie dividend investors. 

* Utilities for example carry very high debt loads and typically grow the dividend very slowly, and the debt can be a problem in certain scenarios.
* REITs like utilities also don't grow their dividend at very high natural rates and like MLPs rely on access to capital markets to grow assets and payout since they don't retain much earnings. This can pose a risk in certain market conditions and affect long term dividend growth profile/risk
* High yielding energy plays are almost always dividend traps due to the cyclicality of the industry, except pipelines and major integrated companies. But never say never, as even companies like Exxon and Chevron are struggling to cover the dividend these days organically



If you're young, I would highly suggest limiting exposure to the higher yielding but slower growing areas to a smaller portion of a dividend portfolio. There is definitely room in a portfolio for stuff like that, but the sweet spot for this approach is the 3-5% yielding stuff capable of sustainably growing the dividend at 6-7% annually, or the 1-2% yielding stuff capable of sustaining 10-15% annual dividend growth. 

Here's what my portfolio looks like (first 1-2 are core positions)

* Telco/Utilities: AT&T, H, RCI.B
* Staples: KO, PM, MO, HSY
* Healthcare: JNJ, AMGN, UNH
* Industrials: CNR, MMM, GD
* Energy: XOM, ENB, KMI, TRP, SLB
* Discretionary: NKE, DIS
* Tech: V, IBM
* Financials: TD, BNS, USB

author: Own-Revenue9302
body: Stay away. This company reminds me of IBM that has been stagnant for years. I think eventually they'll have to cut the div to pay down debt or some other issue. I know it is temping with that div but don't. You'll get screwed in the end. If you wat dividends a better option would be to just go with a dividend ETF instead. Lower yield but also safer and more consistent.

author: Inquisitor1
body:
Americans don't just get a stimulus check, there's been a lot of talk about loan forgiveness.

Where I live about 10 years ago a lot of people who didn't need it took out student loans, and then bought apartments, because the interest was way lower than the regular real estate loan.

Sometimes if your interest is low enough or non existant it's actually cheaper to not pay it back if you have a good investment opportunity. What's IBM dividend, like 5%?

author: CognitivlessApe
body: One up on wallstreet - perer lynch is a good start.  He will tell you to sell.  Invest in companies that use tech, not tech companies themselves because something new and improved will come along shortly.  The companies that use tech will always grow and benefit off new tech.  The companies that make tech will only shine temporarily before the next new thing makes them obsolete- think IBM.  Good luck, your education is the best investment you can make, great call!

author: longhorn00x
body: I don't think all Tech stocks are going to be as immune to this bump as you and others might be thinking. I'd worry more about the company's P/E ratio - as that yield reaches higher - the value of these high revenue/low profit stocks will take a bigger brunt - as the expected long-term value is diminished relative to dividend stocks who are not betting on huge growth. I see a lot of value coming up in tech when this drops off. I think semiconductor companies ($TI, $CREE, $On) might have some higher value coming up. I think keeping a steady portfolio of a combination of these tech stocks and blue-chip high-dividend stocks ($GE, $IBM) could be a decent combination to ride out the upcoming storm. Just be ready to have cash ready prior to that yield breaking 2. Good luck!

body: IBM

author: streetkingz
body: Definitely not. They already did a partnership with IBM to leverage their sales team.  Like Karp said if your in PLTR and you have a short term mind set, your in the wrong place. The numbers will speak for themselves eventually.

author: Nooberling
body:
IBM isn't going anywhere. I don't particularly like them either way, but when it comes to IBM the important letter is the "B." IBM has spent most of a century building a culture and company that gives businesses what they want as reliably as possible. 

That's going to be worth money for quite a while. The problem you have is you think of IBM as a technology company, when it really isn't one anymore.

body: Side note - I bought a value index fund for high dividend/low volatility and gasped in horror when I saw IBM was the largest technology component. Most of the fund was utilities, tobacco, and telecom. I work in tech and it scares me to have Big Blue in my portfolio, however small. Rooting for them but not enough I want to own them.

author: ptwonline
body:
Tech stocks are mostly growth stocks, and growth stocks take a beating when bond yields rise since so much of their valuation is tied to future earnings growth (and those earnings have less value with higher rates).

So basically you'd need to find a tech stock in a value position.  There aren't many since everyone was so bullish on tech.  Closest thing you'll find to it are companies out-of-favor right now, like Intel and IBM.

author: apex1976
body: I fully agree. IBM was in a similar state 21 years ago.

author: upboat_allgoals
body:
>Craig-Hallum

Actually seems a legit research firm. The analyst:

Richard Shannon joined the Equity Research Department at Craig-Hallum Capital Group LLC as a Senior Research Analyst in 2011 and covers stocks in the semiconductor sector. He was the #1 ranked semiconductor analyst in the Wall Street Journal’s Best on the Street survey for 2009 and 2010. Previously, he was a senior analyst at Northland Capital Markets and Piper Jaffray, an associate at UBS, and was an operating systems programmer at IBM for four years. Richard received his BS in Computer & Electrical Engineering from Purdue University, an MBA from the Carlson School at the University of Minnesota and is a CFA charter holder.
